div.p: SOOT, a volatile matter ariſing from wood and other fuel along with the ſmoke ; or rather, it is the ſmoke itſelf condenſed and gathered to the ſides of the chimney. Tho’ once volatile, however, soot cannot be again reſolved into vapour ; but, if diſtilled by a ſtrong fire, yields a volatile alkali and empyreumatic oil, a conſiderable quantity of fixed matter remaining at the bottom of the diſtilling veſſel. If burnt in an open fire, it flames with a thick ſmoke, whence other foot is produced. It is uſed as a material for making ſal ammoniac, and as a manure. See Chemistry, n⁰ 796.; and Agriculture, n⁰ 20.
